Hi C=E9dric, sorry about spelling your name wrong.=F6

>  It's not a matter=
 of preference.  Sometimes I work with streams, sometimes I
>  work with Fi=
le objects and sometimes, I just want the content of the file as
>  an arra=
y of strings or as one big String.  It's unfortunate that the latter
>  is =
still not supported in the JDK.

The reason I am asking is that I always se=
em to prefer a
FileStream/Reader/Writer to working directly with a file. I =
have
noticed that a lot of people seem to have a preference towards working=

with files rather than Streams/Readers/Writers.

If I would want random ac=
ces or something I would opt for working
directly with files but I can't re=
call needing that, I have not
written storages or such. Another occation wh=
en I use file objects is
when doing file system management, creating listin=
g, renaming, working
with directories etc. But when I read/write data i alw=
ays use
streams/readers/writers.

Could you give an example when you think =
that reading/writing directly
to/from a File is better than a stream.

Also=
, when you have your array of Strings or single big string, what
do you typ=
ically do with it? I can think of some things but I am
curious.

One of the=
 reasons I prefer Streams so much is because of the
advantage of being able=
 to direct state to memory rather than disk and
vary source/target media (l=
ike parser might just aswell get its input
from a keyboard, socket, file, m=
emory-location, it should not be bound
to a file). The first point of direc=
ting state to memory is
indispensable when testing.

Also, files imply muta=
ble state of the worst kind. Most of the bugs I
find in my code have to do =
with mutablestate in one way or another and
thus I try to avoid it when pos=
sible. That is also why I am a fan of
interactionbased testing.

Just tossi=
ng some of my reasoning in there to be analysed, questioned
and developed.
